content.description: Start with hand jams as low as possible in the lower left of the diagonally running hand crack. Follow the crack up and right where it flares out. The crux is getting from the flare to the upper lip of the boulder and there are two ways to go about it. Either make a reachy dynamic throw to the lip, or calf hook into the flare and use an undercling to wrestle your way into an insecure heel/toe cam then reach for the lip. Either method is very committing and having a spotter would be very nice psychological pro. The topout is easy enough but not a "gimme" so exercise caution as it would be a nasty fall coming off of the top.
content.location: On the face of the Gritty boulder above the "swimmer's rock"

content.description: Starting on the far right of the front face, traverse left to the sloping crack until you reach the start of "Unknown Herb", Finish on "Unknown Herb".
Start in the prominent crack that "Wrastlin'" follows, but climb straight up the face and out left.Â
content.location: Middle of the Devil's Pool Boulder

content.description: Climb the arete on the far right of the boulder up to the alcove, and follow up to the top.
content.location: Right arete of the Devil's pool boulder

content.description: Start on the juggy left crack and climb straight up
content.location: Left side of Devil's Pool Boulder

content.description: This is a boulder embedded in the hillside, typical of Wissahickon Valley Park. The particularly course nature of the rock makes me question if its actually schist, however it is very solid and grippy (and abrasive). I recently updated the name to "Devil's Pool Boulder" to be consistent with the Gunksapp guide. It gets sun during mid day and the landing is fairly good.
